Open consultation Copyright and ArtiÔ¨Åcial Intelligence

Authors: Department for Science, Innovation & Technology, Department for Culture, Media & Sport

This document outlines an open consultation regarding the application of UK copyright law to the training of artificial intelligence models. The consultation, published on December 17, 2024, is spearheaded by the Department for Science, Innovation & Technology and the Department for Culture, Media & Sport. It addresses a key area of dispute ‚Äì the use of copyrighted material in training AI models ‚Äì and seeks to establish a framework that balances the needs of creative industries and the burgeoning AI sector. The core objective is to provide legal certainty and incentivize innovation while ensuring that human creativity is appropriately rewarded. Currently, rights holders are struggling to control the use of their works in the training process, highlighting a significant challenge for the UK‚Äôs creative and AI industries. The consultation proposes a new framework designed to address these concerns and foster sustainable growth within both sectors. The document emphasizes the importance of both creative industries and the AI sector as key strengths of the UK economy and their contribution to the nation's growth mission. It acknowledges the difficulties faced by rights holders and aims to provide a clear legal pathway forward. The consultation is available online at https://www.gov.uk/government/consultations/copyright-and-artificial-intelligence/copyright-and-artificial-intelligence. The consultation details the need for a legal framework that supports innovation while protecting intellectual property rights, recognizing the complex interplay between these two critical areas of the UK economy. The document‚Äôs purpose is to gather input and shape a future policy that reflects the evolving landscape of AI and copyright.

Key Concepts:

  • Copyright and AI framework
  • Rewarding human creativity
  • Incentivising innovation
  • Application of UK copyright law to AI training
  • Support for AI tool improvement and adoption
  • Licensing frameworks for right holder remuneration and AI developer access
  • Clear labelling of AI outputs to benefit right holders and the public
  • Reform of copyright protections for computer-generated works
  • AI training data and copyright
  • Fair balance between creators and AI developers
